symptoms: Supply air only 5Â°F below return and compressor short cycling in high ambient conditions.

root_cause_hypotheses.hypothesis: Low refrigerant charge from small leak
root_cause_hypotheses.evidence: CH21 indicates low pressure, poor delta-T, dusty outdoor coil exacerbating.
Noisy expansion valve reported, can mimic low charge symptoms.
Excess airflow reduces coil contact, but not confirmed.

most_likely_cause: Refrigerant charge loss causing low suction pressure and short cycling.

recommended_actions.step: Recover refrigerant, weigh charge, and leak-check with nitrogen
recommended_actions.why: Confirms low charge and identifies leak source.

recommended_actions.step: Clean outdoor coil with manufacturer-approved solution
recommended_actions.why: Restores heat exchange and reduces head pressure.

recommended_actions.step: Charge to factory weight and verify superheat/subcool values
recommended_actions.why: Ensures system performance within spec after repairs.

safety_notes: Wear eye protection and gloves when handling refrigerant.
disclaimers: EPA Section 608 certification required for refrigerant handling.

confidence.assessment: Symptoms align with low charge; leak verification pending.

customer_readiness_check.short_reason: Action plan and safety steps are clear for HVAC technician.
